Early-blight.title: Early Blight (Alternaria solani)
Early-blight.short_description: Early blight is a fungal disease that causes dark, concentric ring spots on older leaves, leading to yellowing and premature leaf drop.
symptoms: Brown to black circular spots with concentric rings (target-like appearance)
Starts on lower, older leaves and moves upward
Yellowing and drying of leaves around spots
Stem lesions near soil line and fruit rot on green fruit
causes: Caused by fungus Alternaria solani
Favored by warm (75–85°F), humid weather and prolonged leaf wetness
Spreads via wind, rain splash, and infected debris

treatment_steps.action: Remove infected leaves
treatment_steps.details: Prune and dispose of affected leaves early to slow disease spread.

treatment_steps.action: Apply fungicides
treatment_steps.details: Use chlorothalonil or mancozeb-based fungicides every 7–10 days. Examples: Daconil, Mancozeb Flowable.

treatment_steps.action: Use resistant varieties
treatment_steps.details: Choose cultivars labeled 'EBR' (Early Blight Resistant).

treatment_steps.action: Mulch and improve air flow
treatment_steps.details: Apply straw mulch to prevent soil splash and stake plants for air movement.

treatment_steps.action: Rotate crops
treatment_steps.details: Avoid planting tomatoes or potatoes in the same area for 2–3 years.

prevention: Use disease-free seeds and transplants
Avoid overhead irrigation
Keep foliage dry
Remove debris at end of season
organic_solutions: Copper fungicides (e.g., copper hydroxide)
Bacillus subtilis (Serenade)
Neem oil sprays for mild infections
Compost tea applications weekly
Seaweed extract sprays to boost immunity
Garlic extract natural fungicide
Potassium bicarbonate sprays
chemical_solutions: Chlorothalonil (Daconil): 1.5 tsp/gal water
Mancozeb (Dithane M-45): 2 lb/acre
Azoxystrobin (Quadris) for severe infections
Rotate fungicide classes to prevent resistance
Early-blight.warning: Fungicides work best when applied preventively. Remove infected tissue immediately.

Late-blight.title: Late Blight (Phytophthora infestans)
Late-blight.short_description: Late blight is a devastating oomycete disease that causes dark, water-soaked lesions on leaves, stems, and fruit, often killing plants rapidly.
symptoms: Large, irregular dark-green to brown water-soaked spots
White fungal growth on undersides of leaves in humid conditions
Rapid collapse of foliage and stems
Brown, firm rot on fruit with grayish-white mold
causes: Caused by Phytophthora infestans (same pathogen as potato blight)
Spreads via wind, rain, and infected plant material
Favored by cool (60–75°F) and wet weather

treatment_steps.action: Remove infected plants immediately
treatment_steps.details: Uproot and destroy infected plants completely. Bag and burn if permitted. Do NOT compost infected material.

treatment_steps.action: Apply fungicides preventively
treatment_steps.details: Use chlorothalonil (Bravo Ultrex), mancozeb (Dithane M-45), or copper-based fungicides (Bordeaux mixture). Apply every 5-7 days during wet weather. MUST be applied BEFORE infection for best control.

treatment_steps.action: Optimize irrigation and reduce leaf wetness
treatment_steps.details: Use drip irrigation exclusively - avoid overhead watering. Water early in morning to allow foliage to dry. Increase plant spacing and airflow to reduce humidity in canopy.

treatment_steps.action: Implement strict field sanitation and crop rotation
treatment_steps.details: Remove all plant debris and volunteer plants immediately. Rotate crops for 3+ years. Eliminate nightshade weeds nearby. Cover abandoned piles with black plastic.

treatment_steps.action: Use resistant varieties and early warning systems
treatment_steps.details: Plant cultivars with broad-spectrum genetic resistance to late blight. Implement disease forecasting systems. Take preventive action when conditions favor disease (cool 60-75°F + wet weather).

prevention: Plant certified disease-free seeds
Provide good spacing and airflow
Rotate crops for 3 years or more
Avoid planting near potatoes
Monitor weather forecasts and use late blight prediction models
Scout fields daily during favorable conditions
Eliminate cull piles and volunteer tomatoes/potatoes completely
Plant in sequential crops to avoid losing entire harvest at once
Use raised beds with excellent drainage
organic_solutions: Copper sprays (Bordeaux mixture, copper hydroxide) - every 5-7 days during risk periods
Bacillus subtilis (Serenade) - limited effectiveness, use as part of integrated approach
Neem oil - only for very mild cases, not effective for established infections
Cultural controls: crop rotation, sanitation, resistant varieties are CRITICAL
chemical_solutions: Chlorothalonil (Bravo Ultrex)
Mancozeb (Dithane M-45)
Zoxamide + Mancozeb (Gavel)
Copper-based fungicides
Always rotate fungicide classes to prevent resistance
Late-blight.estimated_recovery_time: Difficult to recover; early intervention critical
Late-blight.warning: Highly contagious and can destroy crops in days. Monitor daily in humid weather. Focus on PREVENTION through resistant varieties and preventive fungicides.

Leaf-mold.title: Leaf Mold (Passalora fulva / Cladosporium fulvum)
Leaf-mold.short_description: Leaf mold affects primarily the foliage, appearing as yellow spots on top and olive-green fuzzy mold underneath. Thrives in high humidity conditions.
symptoms: Pale green to yellow spots on upper leaf surface
Olive-green to gray mold growth under leaves
Leaves curl, wither, and drop prematurely
Rarely affects fruit under normal conditions
causes: Caused by fungus Passalora fulva (Cladosporium fulvum)
Favored by high humidity (>85%) and poor ventilation
Spread by air currents, tools, and water splash

treatment_steps.action: Reduce humidity and improve airflow
treatment_steps.details: Increase ventilation in greenhouses; prune dense foliage. Maintain humidity below 85%.

treatment_steps.action: Apply biological fungicides
treatment_steps.details: Use Trichoderma spp. (OT1, AT2, BT3) at 23 grams per liter - achieves 100% mycelial inhibition in 5 days. Apply preventively before disease symptoms appear.

treatment_steps.action: Apply chemical fungicides
treatment_steps.details: Use chlorothalonil, mancozeb, or azoxystrobin weekly. Cover lower leaf surfaces where disease first appears.

treatment_steps.action: Use resistant varieties
treatment_steps.details: Select cultivars with Cf resistance genes (e.g., Cf-2, Cf-5).

treatment_steps.action: Disinfect greenhouse surfaces
treatment_steps.details: Clean and disinfect greenhouse regularly. Use ozone sterilization if available to control fungal spores.

prevention: Maintain greenhouse humidity below 85%
Ensure good air circulation
Avoid watering in late evening
Sanitize greenhouse surfaces and tools regularly
Remove lower leaves that are close to soil surface
Use ozone sterilization in greenhouses when available
Monitor relative humidity continuously
organic_solutions: Potassium bicarbonate sprays (2-3 gm per liter)
Copper fungicides
Trichoderma harzianum biological control (23 gm/liter)
Neem oil applications (2-3 tablespoons per gallon)
Bacillus subtilis formulations (Trianum V)
Pantoea agglomerans - reduces mycelial growth by 60%+
chemical_solutions: Chlorothalonil (Daconil)
Mancozeb (Dithane M-45)
Azoxystrobin (Quadris)
Triflumizole or polyoxin B for rotation
Leaf-mold.warning: Thrives in humid greenhouses — manage ventilation carefully. Remove lower leaves regularly.

Mosaic-virus.title: Tomato Mosaic Virus (ToMV)
Mosaic-virus.short_description: A viral disease causing mottled yellow-green leaves, distortion, and stunted growth. Extremely persistent on surfaces - NO CHEMICAL CURE EXISTS.
symptoms: Mottled (light and dark green) leaf patterns
Distorted or fern-like leaf shapes
Reduced fruit size and uneven ripening
No mold or rot — symptoms purely visual
causes: Caused by Tomato mosaic virus (ToMV) or Tobacco mosaic virus (TMV)
Spread mechanically through hands, tools, and infected plant debris
Virus can persist in soil and tools for MONTHS
Transmits from tobacco products to plants

treatment_steps.action: Remove and destroy infected plants immediately
treatment_steps.details: Uproot infected plants completely as soon as symptoms appear. Destroy by burning or deep burial (NOT composting). Early removal prevents mechanical spread.

treatment_steps.action: Disinfect all tools, hands, and equipment thoroughly
treatment_steps.details: Use 10% bleach solution or 70% alcohol to disinfect pruning tools, stakes, gloves between EACH plant. Wash hands with soap before handling plants. Virus persists on surfaces for months.

treatment_steps.action: Implement strict sanitation protocols
treatment_steps.details: Avoid smoking near plants (TMV transmits from tobacco). Workers wash hands before entering field. Clean equipment and boots when moving between fields. Sanitize greenhouse surfaces.

treatment_steps.action: Apply biological controls and plant immunity boosters
treatment_steps.details: Use Bacillus subtilis + Pseudomonas fluorescens + brown alga (Sargassum) extract. Studies show this reduces disease severity to 27.46% and inhibits virus accumulation by 86.48%. Apply 100 mL bacterial suspension to rhizosphere.

treatment_steps.action: Use resistant varieties with ToMV/TMV resistance genes
treatment_steps.details: Select varieties labeled 'ToMV-resistant' or 'TMV-resistant'. Resistance genes provide most effective long-term control. Check seed catalogs for resistant cultivars.

prevention: Use certified virus-free seeds from reputable sources
Disinfect tools and hands between EVERY plant - virus extremely persistent
Avoid smoking or using tobacco products near tomato plants
Wash hands thoroughly with soap before handling plants
Remove and destroy infected plants immediately upon detection
Rotate crops for 2+ years with non-solanaceous crops
Control weeds that may harbor the virus
Do NOT compost infected plants or materials
organic_solutions: Biological controls: Bacillus subtilis + Pseudomonas fluorescens - reduce disease severity by up to 73%
Brown alga extract (Sargassum angustifolium) - 100 mL per plant to rhizosphere
Seaweed extract sprays - boost plant defense mechanisms
Neem oil - mild antiviral deterrent (limited effectiveness)
Hot water seed treatment: 50°C for 25 minutes
Sodium hypochlorite seed treatment: 1-1.5% for 10 minutes
NO chemical cure exists - prevention and sanitation are CRITICAL
chemical_solutions: NO CHEMICAL CURE EXISTS
Only preventive sanitation and biological controls work
Focus on plant immunity boosting with seaweed extract and plant growth promoters
Mosaic-virus.estimated_recovery_time: No cure once infected - plants remain infected for life
Mosaic-virus.warning: Tomato Mosaic Virus is EXTREMELY persistent on tools, hands, and surfaces for months. Strict hygiene and sanitation are absolutely critical. There is NO chemical cure - only prevention works. Remove infected plants immediately.

Septoria-leaf-spot.title: Septoria Leaf Spot (Septoria lycopersici)
Septoria-leaf-spot.short_description: A common fungal disease causing numerous small, circular brown leaf spots with light centers, leading to rapid defoliation.
symptoms: Small, circular brown spots with light centers (1–3 mm)
Dark margins around spots
Leaves yellow and drop prematurely
Usually starts on lower leaves first
causes: Caused by fungus Septoria lycopersici
Favored by wet, humid conditions and overhead watering
Spreads through splashing water and infected debris

treatment_steps.action: Remove and destroy infected leaves immediately
treatment_steps.details: Prune affected foliage to reduce spore spread. Destroy by burning or deep burial. Disinfect pruning tools between cuts.

treatment_steps.action: Apply fungicides at first sign of disease
treatment_steps.details: Spray chlorothalonil (Daconil) or copper-based fungicides every 7-10 days. Begin applications preventively before symptoms appear. Ensure thorough coverage of lower leaves.

treatment_steps.action: Improve air circulation and reduce leaf wetness
treatment_steps.details: Stake plants and maintain proper spacing (24-36 inches). Remove suckers and lower lateral growth. Prune excess interior foliage to improve airflow. This reduces leaf wetness critical for spore germination.

treatment_steps.action: Optimize irrigation management
treatment_steps.details: Use drip irrigation or water at plant base only. Water early in the day to allow foliage to dry before nightfall. Avoid overhead watering which splashes spores upward.

treatment_steps.action: Implement crop rotation and sanitation
treatment_steps.details: Rotate away from tomatoes and peppers for 2+ years. Control solanaceous weeds. Remove all crop debris at season end. Use mulch or plastic to prevent soil splash onto leaves.

prevention: Avoid overhead irrigation
Remove plant debris post-season
Use clean seed and resistant varieties
Apply mulch (straw, plastic) to prevent soil splash
Use raised beds to improve drainage
Avoid working in fields when leaves are wet
Scout plants frequently - inspect twice weekly
Start with pathogen-free certified seeds
Maintain balanced fertilization to promote plant vigor
organic_solutions: Copper fungicides (copper hydroxide, copper sulfate) - spray every 7-10 days
Bacillus subtilis formulations (Serenade, Trianum V) - 23 grams per liter
Trichoderma harzianum biological control
Baking soda solution (1 tablespoon per gallon + few drops soap) - alters leaf pH
Neem oil (2-3 tablespoons per gallon) - for early stage control
Compost tea - boost plant immunity
Garlic extract and plant-based fungicides
chemical_solutions: Chlorothalonil (Daconil)
Mancozeb (Dithane)
Copper sulfate combinations
Always rotate fungicide classes to prevent resistance
Septoria-leaf-spot.warning: Rapidly spreads under humid conditions — begin fungicide early. Scout fields twice weekly for early detection.

Yellow-leaf-curl-virus.title: Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus (TYLCV)
Yellow-leaf-curl-virus.short_description: A viral disease transmitted by whiteflies that causes leaf curling, yellowing, and stunted growth. NO CURE - focus on resistant varieties and whitefly control.
symptoms: Upward curling and yellowing of leaves
Stunted growth and reduced fruiting
Thick, leathery leaves with crinkled texture
Flower drop and poor fruit set
causes: Caused by Tomato yellow leaf curl virus (TYLCV)
Transmitted by whiteflies (Bemisia tabaci)
Spreads rapidly in warm, dry conditions
Strong correlation between whitefly density and disease incidence

treatment_steps.action: Control whitefly vector populations aggressively
treatment_steps.details: Use yellow sticky traps (20-30 per acre). Apply neem oil sprays (2% concentration). Introduce Encarsia formosa parasitoid wasps and Beauveria bassiana fungus. Monitor whitefly populations weekly.

treatment_steps.action: Remove and destroy infected plants immediately
treatment_steps.details: Uproot and destroy affected plants as soon as symptoms appear. Remove roots completely after harvest. Eliminate volunteer tomatoes and solanaceous weeds. Bag and burn infected material.

treatment_steps.action: Use TYLCV-resistant varieties with Ty genes
treatment_steps.details: Plant varieties with Ty-1, Ty-2, Ty-3, Ty-3a, or Ty-5 resistance genes (e.g., 'Tyking', 'Tylcv-Res'). Multi-disease resistant lines combining Ty-1/Ty-3 + WF genes show significantly better performance. Resistance never 100% but dramatically reduces disease severity.

treatment_steps.action: Install physical barriers and use reflective mulches
treatment_steps.details: Use fine mesh insect-proof screens (50-mesh) in greenhouses and nurseries to block whiteflies. Install reflective silver or aluminum mulches to deter whitefly landing. Use protective netting for high-value crops.

treatment_steps.action: Apply biopesticides and plant immunity boosters
treatment_steps.details: Spray fungal culture filtrate (F8-culture) or plant-based viricides. Studies show F8-culture filtrate keeps 43-100% of plants healthy vs 0-14% in water control. Apply gibberellin to enhance plant resistance.

prevention: Use Ty-gene resistant varieties (Ty-1, Ty-3, Ty-3a, Ty-5) - most effective prevention
Plant multi-disease and insect-resistant lines (Ty genes + whitefly resistance)
Install insect-proof netting (50-mesh) in nurseries and greenhouses
Use reflective mulches (silver/aluminum) to repel whiteflies
Monitor whitefly populations weekly using yellow sticky traps
Remove volunteer tomatoes and solanaceous weeds - eliminate virus reservoirs
Practice crop rotation with non-host crops (cereals, legumes)
Avoid planting near infected fields - virus spreads 1750-5000m
Plant trap crops (marigolds, maize) around field perimeter
Use certified virus-free seeds and transplants only
Destroy crop debris immediately - remove all roots
Avoid excessive nitrogen - increases plant susceptibility
Maintain balanced nutrition to reduce plant stress
Coordinate area-wide management with neighboring farms
organic_solutions: Neem oil sprays (2% concentration, 2-3 tablespoons per gallon) - repels whiteflies
Yellow sticky traps - 20-30 per acre for monitoring and mass trapping
Biological control: Encarsia formosa parasitoid wasps - highly effective
Beauveria bassiana fungus - infects and kills whitefly nymphs and adults
Fungal culture filtrate (F8-culture) - induces systemic plant immunity

Note: Focus on vector control - NO chemical cure for virus once plant infected
Yellow-leaf-curl-virus.estimated_recovery_time: No cure once infected - plants remain infected for life
Yellow-leaf-curl-virus.warning: TYLCV is HIGHLY contagious via whiteflies. Once infected, plants cannot be cured. Prevention through resistant varieties and aggressive whitefly control is absolutely critical. Temperature affects resistance - breakdown occurs above 30°C.

Bacterial-spot.title: Bacterial Spot (Xanthomonas spp.)
Bacterial-spot.short_description: Bacterial spot is a serious disease affecting tomato leaves, stems, and fruit, causing small dark spots with yellow halos. Copper resistance increasing globally.
symptoms: Small, dark brown to black spots on leaves (1-3mm diameter)
Yellow halo around spots as they age
Spots may coalesce, causing large necrotic areas
Fruit shows small, raised dark spots with white halos
Severe defoliation in advanced stages
causes: Caused by Xanthomonas bacteria (X. euvesicatoria, X. gardneri, X. perforans, X. vesicatoria)
Spreads through water splash, wind-driven rain, and contaminated tools
Favored by warm (75-86°F), humid conditions
Enters through stomata and wounds

treatment_steps.action: Remove and destroy infected plant material immediately
treatment_steps.details: Immediately remove severely infected leaves and plants. Bag and dispose of them (do not compost). Disinfect tools with 10% bleach solution between cuts to prevent pathogen spread.

treatment_steps.action: Apply copper-based bactericides with biological controls
treatment_steps.details: Spray copper hydroxide (Kocide 3000) or copper sulfate fungicides every 7-10 days. Rotate with biological controls like Bacillus subtilis (Serenade) or B. amyloliquefaciens to reduce resistance. Apply in early morning when leaves are dry.

treatment_steps.action: Integrate biological controls and plant growth promoters
treatment_steps.details: Apply Bacillus subtilis, Streptomyces lydicus (Actinovate), or plant extracts (neem, garlic). Studies show biological agents can reduce disease severity by 45-65% when combined with cultural practices.

treatment_steps.action: Improve cultural practices and field sanitation
treatment_steps.details: Space plants properly (24-36 inches apart), use drip irrigation instead of overhead watering, mulch to prevent soil splash. Avoid working with wet plants. Maintain field hygiene by removing crop debris immediately.

treatment_steps.action: Rotate crops and use resistant varieties
treatment_steps.details: Do not plant tomatoes, peppers, or solanaceous crops in the same location for at least 2-3 years. Rotate with non-host crops like corn, beans, or squash. Choose varieties with bacterial spot resistance genes.

Maintain good air circulation between plants

Apply preventive copper sprays in high-risk periods
Use yellow sticky traps to monitor pest populations
Install preventive copper sprays during high-risk periods
Monitor field regularly - inspect plants twice weekly

Bacterial-spot.warning: Bacterial spot is difficult to control once established. Prevention and early detection are critical. Copper sprays have limited effectiveness once symptoms appear.

Use drip irrigation or water at plant base to keep foliage dry
Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with balanced fertilizer (10-10-10 or tomato-specific)
Apply organic fertilizers, compost, and rock dust (Azomite) for trace minerals
Monitor for early signs of pests or diseases - inspect plants twice weekly
Prune suckers and lower branches for better air circulation
Remove lower leaves to prevent soil-borne disease splash
Mulch around plants with straw or organic material to conserve moisture
Provide support with stakes, cages, or trellises
Maintain proper spacing (24-36 inches) for adequate airflow
Apply foliar sprays: compost tea weekly, Epsom salt (1 tbsp/gallon) every 2 weeks
Use aspirin spray (500mg/gallon) every 2-3 weeks to boost plant immune system
Deep plowing before planting to destroy pest eggs and pathogens
Clean and disinfect tools regularly with bleach or alcohol solution
prevention: Inspect plants weekly for early disease detection - scout twice per week minimum
Maintain consistent soil moisture - irregular watering causes stress and disorders
Ensure 8-10 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth
Practice crop rotation annually - 2-3 year rotation with non-solanaceous crops
Remove weeds that compete for nutrients and harbor pests/diseases
Use certified disease-free seeds and transplants
Test soil annually and amend with 3-6 inches of compost
Avoid working with plants when leaves are wet
Install yellow sticky traps for early pest detection
Maintain balanced fertilization - avoid excessive nitrogen
Remove all crop debris at season end - do not compost diseased material
Sanitize stakes, cages, and supports between seasons
Plant resistant varieties when available for your region
Use raised beds with excellent drainage
Implement integrated pest management (IPM) strategies

optimal_conditions.sunlight: 8-10 hours direct sunlight daily for optimal growth
optimal_conditions.watering: 1-2 inches per week, more during flowering and fruiting. Water deeply every 5-7 days rather than frequent shallow watering. Use drip irrigation. Water at base of plants in early morning.

Healthy.warning: Continue preventive maintenance and regular scouting to catch any diseases early.
